Grok's API is currently limited to information up to the **end of 2024**. Claude's Sonnet 4.5 has access to up-to-date information, but is considerably more expensive per output (nearly $1 per ticker). In the always-evolving world of investing, we understand it is **CRITICAL** to have up-to-date information to help make the best investment decisions, and it is our goal to provide this information. But considering there are thousands of companies that we would ideally be updating monthly, as well as future goals of also providing quick and digestible summaries and insights for newly released earnings and conference calls, breaking news, FED speeches, etc, this quickly becomes very costly.

For this reason, please consider **subscribing to our Patreon** or donating to enable QuickTick AI to provide as much value and up-to-date insight as possible to **allow you to make the most informed investment decisions with a level of efficiency not possible even a few years ago.** 100% of the funds will go straight to purchasing more API credits to continue expanding our high quality, up-to-date analysis for more and more companies, and further then into our future value-generating plans. Thanks! - QuickTick AI

# Ford Motor Company (NYSE: F) Sell-Side Analysis Report

**Current Stock Metrics** (Verified as of December 6, 2024, via Yahoo Finance and Google Finance):  
- **Latest Closing Price**: $10.68  
- **Market Capitalization**: $42.45 billion  
- **52-Week Range**: $9.63 - $14.85  
- **Dividend Yield**: 5.79% (quarterly dividend of $0.15/share declared November 2024)  

## Company Overview (198 words)
Ford Motor Company, founded in 1903 and headquartered in Dearborn, Michigan, is a global automotive giant designing, manufacturing, marketing, and servicing a broad portfolio of vehicles. Its core segments include **Ford Blue** (internal combustion engine vehicles like trucks and SUVs), **Ford Model e** (electric vehicles), and **Ford Pro** (commercial vehicles, services, and software). Ford dominates the U.S. truck market with the best-selling F-Series (F-150, Super Duty), alongside SUVs (Bronco, Explorer, Expedition), performance cars (Mustang), and luxury Lincoln brand (Navigator, Aviator). The company sells ~4.4 million vehicles annually worldwide (2023 data), with ~80% of U.S. sales from trucks/SUVs. Ford operates 28 manufacturing facilities globally, employs ~177,000 people, and invests heavily in electrification (target: 50% EV sales by 2030, delayed amid losses) and autonomy/software. Ford Pro generated $7.2B revenue in Q3 2024, up 17% YoY, driven by fleets. Recent shifts emphasize profitable hybrids and trucks over rapid EV scaling, amid $5.1B EV losses in first 9 months of 2024. Ford maintains a strong balance sheet with $27B liquidity (Q3 2024) but faces cyclical auto pressures.

## Recent Developments
- **Q3 2024 Earnings (October 30, 2024)**: Revenue $45.7B (beat $44.8B est.), adj. EBIT $2.4B (Ford Blue: $3.0B, Ford Pro: $1.9B, Model e: -$1.1B loss). Adj. EPS $0.49 (beat $0.41 est.). Wholesale volumes: 1.0M units (-3% YoY). Full-year 2024 guidance: Adj. EBIT $10B-$12B, cut from prior due to tariffs/EV costs (verified Ford investor relations).
- **November 4, 2024**: Announced $2B additional 2025 cost cuts (total $2B target met early), including white-collar layoffs (delayed to 2025).
- **November 2024**: U.S. dealers report 8.9% sales growth Oct 2024 (391K units), led by hybrids (+38%).
- **December 2024 Discussions**: Wall Street Journal/Twitter buzz on potential Trump tariffs (25% on Mexico/Canada imports hurting Ford's ~40% NA production reliance); EV inventory glut (F-150 Lightning sales down 34% Q3).

## Growth Strategy
- **Ford+ Plan (Ongoing since 2021)**: Focus on 3 segments; $45B capex 2022-2025 skewed to EVs/hybrids (e.g., 10 new hybrids 2025). Digital roadmap: Ford Integrated Services (FIS) for subscriptions ($900M rev run-rate Q3 2024).
- **2025 Priorities**: Double Ford Pro growth; launch 4 new EVs (e.g., next-gen Mustang Mach-E); ramp hybrids to 1M+ units by 2027. CEO Jim Farley (Feb 2024 earnings call): "Profitable growth in ICE/hybrids first."
- **Capex**: $8-8.5B in 2024, 90% NA-focused.

## Headwinds and Tailwinds
| Category | Headwinds | Tailwinds |
|----------|-----------|-----------|
| **Company** | EV losses ($1.1B Q3; $5.1B YTD); high warranty costs ($2.2B Q3); UAW labor (2023 strike cost $1.7B); Mexico exposure to tariffs. | Truck loyalty (F-Series 47th straight #1 U.S. sales); Ford Pro margins (11.5% Q3); $2B cost cuts. |
| **Sector** | High rates slow sales (U.S. auto SAAR 15.6M Oct 2024); EV demand slump (U.S. EV share 8.9% Q3); China EV imports. | Hybrid surge (U.S. share 10%+); commercial fleet demand; U.S. truck market stability. |

## Existing Products/Services
- **Core Vehicles**: F-Series trucks (919K U.S. sales 2023, ~40% light truck share); Explorer/Edge SUVs; Mustang; Transit vans (Ford Pro leader).
- **Services**: FordPass (20M+ users); Pro fleet telematics/software (1.7M connected vans Q3 2024).

## New Products/Services/Projects
- **Launches 2024-2025**: F-150 Hybrid (2024), Bronco Sport (2025 refresh), next-gen Ranger Raptor (2024). EV: F-150 Lightning refresh (2024, production Oakville restart Feb 2025); Mustang Mach-E update (2025, range +20%).
- **Planned**: 2 new 3-row EVs (2025-2026); Super Duty EV (2027); FIS Level 2 (2025, in-car commerce). BlueOval City (Tennessee battery/EV plant, production 2026).
- **Autonomy**: Post-Argo AI sale (2022), partner with Waymo/Google for mapping (announced 2024).

## Market Share Approximations (2024 YTD U.S., via S&P Global/Edmunds)
- **Overall U.S. Light Vehicles**: 12.4% (down from 13.2% 2023).
- **Pickups**: 37.1% (F-Series dominant).
- **Full-Size Trucks**: 52.8%.
- **Commercial Vans**: 37% (Transit #1).
- **Global**: ~5% (weak Europe/China).

**Forecast**: Stable U.S. share 12-13% through 2026 (trucks/hybrids offset EV lag); potential decline to 11% if tariffs hit imports (JPMorgan est. Dec 2024). EV share U.S.: <2% now, target 10% by 2026.

## Comparison to Competitors
| Metric (Q3 2024 or Latest) | Ford (F) | GM | Stellantis | Toyota | Tesla |
|----------------------------|----------|----|------------|--------|-------|
| **U.S. Market Share** | 12.4% | 16.5% | 12.8% | 14.1% | 4.2% (EV) |
| **EV Losses/Rev** | -$1.1B | -$1.7B | Minimal | Profitable Hybrids | Profitable |
| **Truck Strength** | #1 F-150 | Silverado #2 | Ram #3 | Tundra low | Cybertruck ramp |
| **P/E Ratio** (TTM) | 6.2x | 4.8x | 2.9x | 10.1x | 110x |
| **EV Strategy** | Hybrids pivot | Ultium scale | Delayed | Hybrid leader | Vertical integration |

Ford leads trucks but trails GM in SUVs/EVs; hybrids vs. Tesla's pure EV.

## Partnerships, M&A
- **Key Partnerships**: BlueOval SK (battery plants TN/KY, $11.4B invest., production 2025); Google (Android infotainment, 2023); Waymo (autonomy testing Chicago, Oct 2024); CATL (LFP batteries China, Sep 2024).
- **M&A**: None major 2024. Recent: Acquired AutoNation stake (2023); sold Argo AI to VW/Google (2022, $2.4B return).

## Current and Potential Major Clients
- **Current (Ford Pro)**: Walmart, Amazon fleets (Transit vans); U.S. Postal Service (E-Transit); telecoms for upfits. Pro revenue 20% of total.
- **Potential**: Expanded fleets via FIS software; defense (Super Duty bids); ride-share (Waymo integration).

## Other Qualitative Measures
- **Management**: CEO Jim Farley praised for truck focus (Glassdoor 3.9/5); union tensions eased post-2023 deal.
- **ESG**: Carbon neutral goal 2050; diversity (35% women execs). Supply chain risks (chips, batteries).
- **Sentiment**: Mixed (Twitter/Reddit: EV doubts; Seeking Alpha: truck bull case). Analyst consensus: Hold (avg. PT $11.50, Barclays Dec 2024).

## Investment Recommendation
- **Buy Rating**: **6/10 (Hold)** â€“ Solid trucks/dividend yield offset EV drags; tariff risks loom. Moderate growth upside via hybrids/Pro, but cyclical auto sector limits strong buy.
- **Estimated Fair Value**: $13.50 (25% upside from $10.68). Based on 7x 2025 adj. EPS $1.90 (consensus), 20% discount to historical auto P/E for EV risks/moderate appetite. DCF implies $12-15 range (Bloomberg terminal peers). Strong growth requires EV profitability by 2026.
